See the Stunning Artworks by the Winners and Featured Artists of This Boundary-Pushing National Portrait Competition
The seventh edition of the triennial Outwin Boochever contest showcases contemporary artists‚Äô novel approaches to their subjects
Much of the permanent collection at the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Portrait Gallery reflects the long-venerated portraiture tradition: a straight-ahead, realistic depiction of a known individual. Nothing in life is static, however, including how artists approach portraiture. That idea is central to the Portrait Gallery‚Äôs triennial Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition. The 35 artists selected for the 2025 contest employ video, fiber art, photographs, multi-media and performances to invite the viewer into the subject‚Äôs world. Their work will be displayed at the museum‚Äôs new ‚ÄúThe Outwin 2025: American Portraiture Today‚Äù exhibition.
The exhibition shows that ‚Äúportraiture is an art form that is always evolving,‚Äù and ‚Äúincredibly capacious,‚Äù says National Portrait Gallery curator Ta√≠na Caragol, who was one of seven jurors selecting works for the show. The works can represent an individual, a group of people or a community, and can even be faceless or reference architecture and landscapes. ‚ÄúThat is what keeps the competition really fresh at each iteration,‚Äù she says.
Three artists included in the showcase of 34 portraits were selected to receive the top honors: Kameron Neal of New York, Jared Soares of Washington, D.C. and David Antonio Cruz of New York. The top three winners earn $25,000, $10,000 and $7,500, respectively.
Quick facts: A celebration of portraiture
- ‚ÄúThe Outwin 2025: American Portraiture Today,‚Äù featuring 34 portraits by 35 artists, is on view at the National Portrait Gallery from January 24 to August 30, 2026. After the exhibition completes its run at the museum, it will tour the U.S.
- In addition to the juror-chosen winners, a ‚ÄúPeople‚Äôs Choice‚Äù awardee receives $500. Visitors make that choice known by voting at a digital kiosk in the exhibition space. Voting is also open online.
- The museum‚Äôs Teen Portrait Competition received more than 1,100 entries from students in 48 states, Guam, Puerto Rico and Washington, D.C. Matilda Myers of Maryland won in the 13-to-15-year-old age group, and Kate Stermer of California won in the 16-to-17-year-old group. Their work will be on view in a video presentation at the National Portrait Gallery.
First-prize winner Neal will also be paid to make a portrait of a living well-known individual, chosen in consultation with the artist and the Portrait Gallery. The completed work will become part of the permanent collection‚Äîa fact that ‚Äúmakes it very desirable for artists to participate‚Äù in the Outwin competition, says Caragol.
Neal says that being chosen ‚Äúfeels like a dream come true.‚Äù To show work at the National Portrait Gallery is a ‚Äúrich and important opportunity to be able to kind of reflect the world back onto itself,‚Äù he adds.
The multi-disciplinary artist‚Äôs Down the Barrel (of a Lens) is a two-screen video installation that draws upon thousands of hours of declassified surveillance video taken by the New York Police Department from 1960 to 1980. The 2023 piece often focuses on people of color, including Martin Luther King, Jr., and protesters, but also average citizens suspected of criminal activity or just caught on camera. The NYPD‚Äôs surveillance methods were deemed unconstitutional in 1985.
Neal had access to the archival footage during a period as public artist-in-residence at New York City‚Äôs Department of Records. The video is a portrait of New Yorkers at the time but also captures ‚Äúa charged moment in American history,‚Äù the artist says.
Viewers of the installation are both surveilled and surveying simultaneously. ‚ÄúIt kind of creates this discomfiting feeling,‚Äù says Neal. It seems that the video subjects ‚Äúare looking at one another, and they‚Äôre also looking at you and you‚Äôre looking at them.‚Äù
The work draws a line to the present, where surveillance via cellphone cameras seems almost all-encompassing, he says. ‚ÄúOversharing comes at a cost that I think we might not fully understand right now,‚Äù says Neal.
Second-prize winner Soares‚Äô 2023 photograph Misidentified by Artificial Intelligence: Alonzo and Carronne is another meditation on surveillance. The portrait of Alonzo Sawyer, who was falsely accused of a crime, and his wife, Caronne, appeared in a New Yorker article that detailed his ordeal. AI-powered facial recognition technology convinced authorities that he was responsible for the assault of a bus driver. He was arrested, jailed and threatened with lengthy prison time before eventually being released after a battle to prove his innocence.
Soares says when he went to meet the couple, he was thinking about the ‚Äúuniqueness of an individual face.‚Äù That led him to prominently feature Alonzo‚Äôs face in the picture. He also wanted to highlight the couple‚Äôs relationship and make an image that ‚Äúsuggests love, care and tenderness.‚Äù
This photograph was also personal to Soares. Being a person of color added another layer to his process, he notes: ‚ÄúAm I next? Is my cousin next?‚Äù he thought. Sawyer, a Black man, ‚Äúlived my nightmare,‚Äù Soares says. According to the New Yorker story, ‚ÄúIn 2019, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, a federal agency, published a study revealing that many facial-recognition systems falsely identified Black and Asian faces between ten and a hundred times more frequently‚Äù than white ones.
Third-prize winner Cruz‚Äôs 2023 painting isaiditoncebefore,butnowIfeelitevenmore_feelin‚Äôpretty,pretty,pretty is a celebration of Cruz and his lifelong friend, Archel. ‚ÄúFeelin‚Äô pretty, pretty, pretty,‚Äù is something the two would say before going out, says Cruz. The painting depicts the pair in colorful clothing and adorned with jewelry. Cruz has an arm around Archel, who holds his hand. Their heads lean toward each other and are encompassed in a bubble. ‚ÄúThey are pretty much existing in the same space, and same world,‚Äù says Cruz, who says that Archel was one of the first people to pose for him when he started as an artist.
Cruz is known for his celebrations of Black and brown queer culture and has highlighted the bonds of ‚Äúchosen families‚Äù in his paintings, drawings and installations. Being selected for the Outwin is an incredible honor, says Cruz, adding that it ‚Äúdefines American portraiture.‚Äù
Among the past winners of the Outwin are Bo Gehring (2013), Amy Sherald (2016) and Hugo Crosthwaite (2019). The competition was first held in 2006. It was made possible by an endowment from a former docent at the National Portrait Gallery, Virginia Outwin Boochever. The museum volunteer, who had graduate-level art training and was a collector, wanted to emulate an annual competition held at the National Portrait Gallery in London, and to directly benefit artists.
The criteria for entry are: The works must have been made within the three years after the prior competition and artists must be over age 18 and be living and working in the U.S., including Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa and the U.S. Virgin Islands. There is no theme. So far, the rules do not prohibit the use of artificial intelligence, but none of the portraits selected for the 2025 exhibition employed the technology, says Caragol.
For the 2025 competition, the museum received more than 3,300 entries from 49 states, Washington, D.C. and Puerto Rico. The jurors initially reviewed the thousands of entries online, which led to carpal tunnel syndrome for a few, jokes Caragol. Once the semi-finalists were selected, the artists shipped their work to the museum for closer inspection.
The seven jurors looked not only for synthesis between form and message, but also for ‚Äúa work that has something to say and that is carefully executed, that conveys mastery of a technique,‚Äù she says. Entries are anonymous and the artist chooses how much information they include with the entry.
Caragol was joined by Carla Acevedo-Yates, a curator for the upcoming documenta 16 exhibition in Kassel, Germany; University of Pennsylvania art history professor Huey Copeland; artists LaToya Ruby Frazier and Daniel Lind-Ramos; National Portrait Gallery curator Charlotte Ickes; and Rhea L. Combs, the museum‚Äôs director of curatorial affairs.
The competition has evolved along with the artists, says Ickes. Earlier editions required the subject to be living and that there be a live meeting between subject and artist. Now, artists can portray subjects they have never met or who are no longer living.
Many artists have begun using archival materials to create portraits. That practice, Ickes says, ‚Äúis also reflected more and more in our collection.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt shows a kind of transformation of what we think about the artistic encounter with a portrait subject or what portraiture can be,‚Äù she says.

Officials have proposed building a mini-Sphere in Maryland‚Äôs National Harbor. One-third the size of the original, the structure would cost about $1 billion
Since its grand opening in 2023, the Las Vegas Sphere has quickly emerged as one of the most viral venues in the worlds of music, film, sports and pop culture.
Stretching more than 500 feet wide, the $2.3 billion dome has hosted a 40-show U2 residency, The Wizard of Oz screenings, the National Hockey League draft and UFC 306, among other events. Videos of Orbi, the massive emoji who ‚Äúlives‚Äù on its exterior LED screen and rises with the desert sun, have been shared widely online. Last month, Timoth√©e Chalamet became the first person to stand atop the Sphere while promoting his new film, Marty Supreme.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a paradigm shift in live music and visual [presentation],‚Äù Trey Anastasio, lead guitarist of the rock band Phish, who played at the Sphere in April 2024, told CNN‚Äôs Jason Morris. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs ‚Ä¶ an exciting new canvas.‚Äù
Now, versions of the structure are being planned in other locations, including Abu Dhabi, where a full-size replica Sphere is already under construction. This month, officials announced a proposal to build a new‚Äîalbeit smaller‚ÄîSphere outside Washington, D.C.
‚ÄúOur focus has always been on creating a global network of Spheres across forward-looking cities,‚Äù James L. Dolan, the executive chairman and CEO of Sphere Entertainment, says in a statement.
With a planned 6,000 seats, the new mini-Sphere would be located in National Harbor in Maryland. It would be roughly one-third the size of the 18,000-seat original, though it will feature many of the same bells and whistles. These include what Sphere Entertainment claims to be the highest-resolution LED screens in the world; immersive surround sound technology; ‚Äúhaptic‚Äù vibrating feedback chairs; and the capacity for wind, scent, environmental and temperature changes.
In a press conference held earlier this week, officials estimated that the mini-Sphere‚Äôs construction would generate more than 2,700 jobs, per WTOP. Once it‚Äôs complete, it‚Äôs expected to support around 5,000 jobs. It‚Äôs projected to generate $1 billion in economic activity annually through artist residencies, sporting events and corporate functions.
The venue is expected to cost $1 billion to build, supported by both private and public funds, including $200 million in incentives, the Washington Post‚Äôs Erin Cox, Travis M. Andrews and Ethan Beck report. Some of these benefits, though, are subject to a public vote. Sphere Entertainment would also be required to forego up to $130 million in future tax revenue and construct a $40 million public parking garage.
Reactions to the proposal have been mixed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Sphere, so it‚Äôs really exciting,‚Äù Charmagne Reyes, a local resident, tells WUSA‚Äôs Ittai Sopher and Alexis Wainwright. ‚ÄúBut the traffic would be much worse because it‚Äôs the National Harbor. Whenever there are big events, it‚Äôs always backed up.‚Äù
Fun fact: The record-setting Sphere
Located near the Las Vegas Strip, the original entertainment venue is billed as the largest spherical building in the world.Concerns also linger over potential light pollution from the venue‚Äôs exterior LED screen, which officials say will feature both advertisements and art. The issue was the primary sticking point in a proposal to bring Sphere to London, which was rejected in 2023 after Mayor Sadiq Khan said the venue would bring ‚Äúunacceptable harm to hundreds of residents,‚Äù according to Dezeen‚Äôs Cajsa Carlson.
If the mini-Sphere project moves forward, it will be the centerpiece of an already well-established entertainment hub. The 350-acre National Harbor, home to 160 stores and 40 restaurants, is visited by 15 million people each year, per the New York Times‚Äô Christine Hauser.
‚ÄúMaryland has a long history of providing world-class entertainment, and we could not be more excited to work with Sphere Entertainment to bring this cutting-edge project to life,‚Äù Maryland Governor Wes Moore says in the statement. ‚ÄúThis will be one of the largest economic development projects in Prince George‚Äôs County history‚Äîproving once again our state is the best place in the country to bring dreams to life.‚Äù
According to Washingtonian‚Äôs Tristan Espinoza, no timeline has yet been set for the mini-Sphere‚Äôs construction, as the venue still needs county and state approvals to move forward.

The Penguins That Thrive‚Äîand the Ones Left Behind‚Äîas Antarctica Warms
A new decade-long study tracked 37 penguin colonies and found that the birds are breeding earlier. The shift marks one way among many that climate change is transforming life at the bottom of the world
Key takeaways: Penguins face an ecosystem of cascading changes
- As the Antarctic warms, penguins‚Äô lifestyles are shifting because of less sea ice and threats to krill, which many of the birds eat.
- A new study finds that Ad√©lie, chinstrap and gentoo penguins have advanced their breeding seasons by roughly two weeks over the past decade, potentially increasing competition between species.
The ink-dark seas were glassy and the conditions mild in one of the most rapidly warming environments on Earth. Here live the humpbacks and orcas, seals and penguins, albatrosses and icefish‚Äîdisparate species bound together by cold water, seasonal ice and the narrow margins of survival at the bottom of the world.
The engine of our Zodiac‚Äîa small but sturdy boat with a rigid hull and rubber pontoons‚Äîemits a steady hum as we move toward a towering mountain, gliding past icebergs sprinkled with penguins and the soft, percussive poofs of humpback whale blows in the distance. A small, charcoal-colored seabird with a narrow white stripe at the base of its tail skims low over the ocean, its feet pitter-pattering along the surface, seeming to walk on water.
‚ÄúA Wilson‚Äôs storm petrel,‚Äù Tom Hart acknowledges through a gentle, gap-toothed smile. ‚ÄúI love those.‚Äù But Hart, a penguinologist, is most interested in the flightless black-and-white birds quintessential to Antarctica‚Äôs landscape.
Our boat threads its way through a mosaic of ice amid the archipelago fringing the Antarctic Peninsula on one of the first days of 2026. Thunderous rumbles‚Äîthe sound of glaciers shifting and settling‚Äîroll through the air, giving a sense of a landscape that‚Äôs very much alive. Jagged mountains loom at a scale that defies comprehension; it feels as if you could never open your eyes or ears widely enough to take it all in. Across one craggy peak, dark seams slice through snow and stone, intersecting in the shape of an ‚Äúx‚Äù that seems to mark the spot of our destination: the penguin colony at its base.
A cacophony of braying calls and guttural squawks pours from the gentoos as we draw nearer, ricocheting off the rock and ice. Hart, a conservation biologist at Oxford Brookes University, and his colleague, Peter Long, unload a small drone from its case, checking its batteries and the wind conditions. As Hart prepares to launch the device, he emphasizes precision over spectacle. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to collect as much information as possible while leaving no trace,‚Äù he says.
The drone rises to map the colony from above‚Äîone more data point in a growing archive. Its aerial imagery will be folded into Penguin Watch, a major citizen science project that Hart founded more than 15 years ago to track penguin populations via drones and time-lapse cameras placed across Antarctica. Now those cameras have produced the most comprehensive long-term record of penguin breeding ever assembled.
In a new, decade-long study published in the Journal of Animal Ecology on Monday, Hart and his colleagues used this network of 77 cameras to track breeding patterns across 37 penguin colonies on the Antarctic Peninsula and sub-Antarctic islands. The results show that penguins are arriving at nesting sites almost two weeks earlier, on average, than they did just ten years ago‚Äîadjusting their life cycles in response to rapidly warming conditions.
The changes uncovered by Hart and his team are not unfolding evenly across Antarctica‚Äôs three sentinel species. Over the past decade, Ad√©lie and chinstrap penguins shifted their breeding earlier by ten days, on average. Gentoo penguins, meanwhile, started their nesting season an average of 13 days earlier‚Äîthe fastest shift in the timing of life cycle events ever recorded in a bird.
The cost of being a ‚Äòperfect Antarctic species‚Äô
Ad√©lies and chinstraps‚ÄîAntarctic specialist species that evolved alongside sea ice and feed almost exclusively on krill‚Äîare increasingly constrained by the warming conditions and unstable food supplies. Gentoo penguins, by contrast, are ecological generalists. They nest on rocky surfaces, remain near their colonies year-round and can switch to hunting fish when krill are scarce.
Even small changes in temperature appear to be driving that shift. ‚ÄúOne degree makes a huge difference in what‚Äôs suitable for a gentoo versus an Ad√©lie,‚Äù Hart says. ‚ÄúIt can mean the difference between snow and ice‚Äîand it fundamentally changes the landscape here.‚Äù
As a result, gentoo colonies have been able to expand into regions once dominated by their more ice-dependent counterparts. Gentoo numbers on the peninsula have surged over the past three decades, more than tripling at many sites, while chinstrap and Ad√©lie populations have declined sharply‚Äîby as much as 75 percent at some of the same colonies.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre roughly gaining one gentoo for each chinstrap and Ad√©lie that we lose,‚Äù Hart says. ‚ÄúThe pattern is not universal. In East Antarctica, where warming has been slower, ice-dependent species are faring far better. But here, they‚Äôre doing really poorly.‚Äù
The dramatic scale of gentoo movement caught the researchers off guard. Using a combination of modeling and genetic data, Heather J. Lynch, a quantitative ecologist at Stony Brook University and a co-author of the paper, estimates that roughly 17 percent of all gentoo penguins on the Antarctic Peninsula are now breeding at the southernmost colonies‚Äînumbers that few experts anticipated from a species long thought to return to the same breeding sites each year. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got this exploding population and a site-faithful species that‚Äôs suddenly on the move,‚Äù Lynch says. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just not behaving the way we thought they would.‚Äù
That expansion is being amplified by the timing shifts revealed by the new research: Gentoo penguins are advancing their arrival at breeding sites faster than the other species are, weakening the long-standing staggered breeding schedule that once reduced competition between penguins. As warming shrinks sea ice and alters krill availability, gentoos‚Äô flexible diet and tolerance for less icy conditions may give them an edge‚Äîallowing them to arrive earlier, claim nest sites and compete more directly with the other penguins.
For Ad√©lies and chinstraps, finely tuned over millions of years to occupy a narrow Antarctic niche, the pace of environmental change may simply be too fast. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve evolved to become the perfect Antarctic species,‚Äù Hart says. ‚ÄúBut the peninsula is changing so quickly, they can‚Äôt adapt to it.‚Äù
A threshold crossed on the Antarctic Peninsula
Antarctica is no stranger to loss. As the planet warms and the freezing line creeps poleward, wintry weather is beginning to loosen its grip on landscapes once locked in ice. The polar regions are heating more than three times faster than the rest of the world‚Äîabout 0.6 degrees Celsius per decade‚Äîand along the Antarctic Peninsula, that pace quickens again. There, temperatures have climbed by nearly 3 degrees Celsius over the past half century, warming several times faster than the continental average.
If you were to hold your hand in a thumbs-up position, Antarctica would be the broad palm and fingers, while the Antarctic Peninsula would be the thumb itself‚Äîa long, narrow reach of land extending north toward South America. And along its western edge, climate change is unfolding fastest. That narrow finger of land and archipelago has become one of the most rapidly warming places on Earth.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an entirely different system when it‚Äôs frozen versus when it‚Äôs unfrozen,‚Äù says Ken Mankoff, a senior scientific programmer and climate scientist contractor at NASA who was not involved in the study. ‚ÄúThe Antarctic Peninsula is crossing that threshold. As ice is lost, you see more mass loss and more fresh water entering the ocean, which in turn alters ecosystems and ocean circulation.‚Äù
Those changes are not abstract. As our small Zodiac crosses the Gerlache Strait with relative ease, Hart gestures toward the deep blue around us‚Äîwaters that, he explains, would have been capped by seasonal ice just 50 years ago.
Sea ice, the frozen ocean surface that expands each austral winter and contracts in summer, forms the foundation of Antarctica‚Äôs food web. Along its underside, ice algae bloom, fueling winter productivity in the Southern Ocean. Antarctic krill depend on the algae for food and shelter, particularly during their larval stages. Penguins, seals, whales and seabirds depend on krill in turn.
As warming air and ocean temperatures erase days and weeks of winter sea ice, that foundation weakens. Krill lose both a primary food source and the physical refuge that helps them survive the winter.
The loss of sea ice also opens Antarctica in another way. Waters once sealed off by thick, seasonal ice now remain navigable for longer stretches of the year, loosening a barrier that for centuries limited who‚Äîand what‚Äîcould reach the Southern Ocean. Fishing vessels without ice-breaking capabilities can now travel farther south, extending the footprint of industrial activity into waters that were once largely inaccessible. That expanded access has intensified pressure on an already heavily fished krill population, even as climate change simultaneously erodes their habitat. Rising ocean acidity may compound that stress, interfering with krill‚Äôs ability to form calcified exoskeletons. From above and below, their world is narrowing.
And the consequences of losing sea ice extend beyond ecology and economics, reaching into the physics of how the planet absorbs heat. ‚ÄúWhen you have sea ice, you‚Äôre reflecting most of the incoming energy,‚Äù Mankoff explains. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bright white, so it bounces sunlight back into space. When you remove that sea ice, most of that energy is absorbed by the dark ocean instead,‚Äù raising its temperature.
An ecosystem in flux
For penguins nesting along the Antarctic Peninsula, those environmental changes are unfolding at an extraordinary pace. The research team‚Äôs temperature log shows that colony sites are warming roughly four times faster‚Äîabout 0.3 degrees Celsius per year‚Äîthan the continental average of 0.07 degrees.
Even as that warming puts some penguins at risk, however, Lynch notes that what‚Äôs emerging is not necessarily a simple story of collapse‚Äîbut one of transition. As conditions warm, sub-Antarctic species such as gentoo, king and macaroni penguins are thriving in places once dominated by Antarctic specialists like Ad√©lies. The shift raises difficult ethical questions about what it means to conserve an ecosystem in flux: whether success should be measured by the preservation of historical communities or by the persistence of life itself.
Lynch speculates that numerically, total penguin numbers in parts of the region may not even be declining: Gains in adaptable species could be offsetting losses of more vulnerable ones. The continent isn‚Äôt becoming empty. ‚ÄúWe are seeing a big transition from an Antarctic avian community to a sub-Antarctic avian community,‚Äù like the one on the island of South Georgia, she says. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs happening really quickly.‚Äù
To Hart, that speed‚Äîand the shift it signals‚Äîmatters as much as the numbers themselves. ‚ÄúYou have crashes in two species and an increase in one,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a fundamental change in an entire ecosystem.‚Äù

How Historically Black Schools Create and Preserve Their Own History Through Amazing Artifacts, From Paintings to Marching Band Hats
For nearly 200 years, HBCUs have educated Black Americans. Now, a new exhibition highlights special objects from five universities
In February 1837, the African Institute was established in Cheyney, Pennsylvania, at the bequest of Quaker philanthropist Richard Humphreys. He had designated $10,000, a tenth of his estate, ‚Äúto instruct the descendants of the African race in school learning, in the various branches of the mechanic arts, trades and agriculture, in order to prepare and fit and qualify them to act as teachers.‚Äù
Today, the school is called Cheyney University, the first of what would later be known as historically Black colleges and universities, or HBCUs. According to the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Museum of African American History and Culture (NMAAHC), from the 1860s to 1900, more than 90 of these institutions were established‚Äîincluding Shaw University, the first to be founded after the Civil War. The Higher Education Act of 1965 noted that HBCUs ‚Äúhave contributed significantly to the effort to attain equal opportunity through postsecondary education for Black, low-income and educationally disadvantaged Americans.‚Äù
Now the museum is telling the stories of these schools with a new exhibition, ‚ÄúAt the Vanguard: Making and Saving History at HBCUs,‚Äù which celebrates the many contributions of the institutions to American life. ‚ÄúAt the Vanguard‚Äù features a collection of objects culled from the museum‚Äôs partnerships with five historically Black universities: Clark Atlanta, Florida A&M, Jackson State, Texas Southern and Tuskegee.
Four bricks handmade by Tuskegee University students illustrate the very material that composed the campus. ‚ÄúMany of the buildings were created by students,‚Äù says Deborah Tulani Salahu-Din, a researcher in Black American literary history who helped curate the exhibition. ‚ÄúThey took classes in brickmaking and then they made the bricks and used them in the construction of many of the buildings on campus.‚Äù Some students were even able to help build the school in lieu of paying tuition.
Quick fact: A new exhibition about HBCUs
‚ÄúAt the Vanguard: Making and Saving History at HBCUs‚Äù is open until July 19, 2026, at the National Museum of African American History and Culture.
Other artifacts on view include an oil painting by American artist William H. Johnson, lent by the Clark Atlanta University Art Museum, and a mixed-media sculpture by contemporary Cameroonian artist Franck Kemkeng Noah, lent by the University Museum at Texas Southern.
‚ÄúHBCUs played the role in providing platforms and showcasing works that would otherwise just go neglected,‚Äù Salahu-Din says.
‚ÄúAt the Vanguard‚Äù also features objects from famous figures in Black American history, such as George Washington Carver‚Äôs typewritten notes about peanut oil and a rare 1942 printing of For My People by poet Margaret Walker, from Tuskegee and Jackson State Universities, respectively.
Walker was an English scholar at Jackson State, where she founded the Institute for the Study of the History, Life and Culture of Black People in 1968. She also organized a festival that brought Black women writers together from across the country to showcase their work and commune over the craft.
In ‚Äúcollecting Black material culture and their own institutional histories,‚Äù NMAAHC African diaspora curator Joanne T. Hyppolite says, HBCUs have done ‚Äúincredible work.‚Äù It‚Äôs ‚Äúsomething they‚Äôve been doing since the late 1800s, at a time when other museums and archives didn‚Äôt see the value of the content in that history and safeguarding it so that other people can use it in the future.‚Äù
Painter Hale Woodruff established the first permanent fine arts program at a Southern HBCU, at Clark Atlanta University, and in the 1940s, persuaded the school to create an annual juried art competition. Much like Walker, he used his position as HBCU faculty to prop up other Black creatives in an otherwise stifling political and social climate.
‚ÄúHBCUs saw the value of Black cultural production and Black aesthetics in ways that other audiences probably didn‚Äôt understand,‚Äù Hyppolite says. ‚ÄúThey encouraged students to look at their communities, their landscapes, their families, and paint from that, from what they know and what they saw. And in doing so, they created this incredible repository of Black life and Black history.‚Äù
And while popular understandings of historically Black colleges may conjure a familiar image‚Äîmarching bands, majorettes and the Divine Nine sororities and fraternities‚Äîno two schools are exactly alike. Hyppolite makes a point of emphasizing their diversity: They‚Äôre big and small, based in the city and the country, and public and private.
After its time at NMAAHC, ‚ÄúAt the Vanguard‚Äù will take a tour through the five schools that contributed to the collection. As a former HBCU faculty member, Jeanelle Hope, the museum‚Äôs curator of entrepreneurship and innovation, looks forward to giving the students an opportunity to engage with their schools‚Äô histories on a deeper level.
In Hope‚Äôs experience, students don‚Äôt visit their campuses‚Äô archives and art museums as much as they could. ‚ÄúAnd oftentimes, they aren‚Äôt aware of the rich history of their campuses,‚Äù she says.
From the inception of the first HBCU 189 years ago to now, the schools have been conductors and historians of Black life.
‚ÄúHBCUs are part of the American narrative,‚Äù Salahu-Din says, ‚Äúlike Black people are part of American history and culture.‚Äù
